nodes.bodyText: I wonder if, as useful as this is, copying it is an anti-pattern?

status Result is never handled or logged, which may cause potential confusion
Albeit this is an extreme edge case anyway
I renamed it from statusResult to notUsed to make it clear it is intentional. Not sure I can do any better there since regardless the result we always raise the original exception.

This code doesn't actually work. When you use compose, you need to return Future and not just complete some Promise defined outside. So I don't think you can mix onComplete and compose so easily. I was thinking to rewrite it whole to compose, but it seemed lot more ugly than with onComplete mainly because these special handlings where we return the original errors etc.
if the get fails, we just hang until timeout as the promise is never addressed. We should use a failure handler (preferably with a compose(successhandler, failhandler)
I can rewrite it to compose(..., ...). But I think the current code is correct. It fails the promise at the end of the method.

What is the purpose behind a new type of exception here?
Just so that a status can be retreieved from it?
Wouldn't it make sense for the reconciler to catch any exceptions and construct the status prior to ending the reconcile?

I'm not sure how exactly do you mean it. But we need to be able to pass back the status and yet report that there was an error. The upper class does not have all the info to construct the status. So throwing back just the original exception is not enough and returning success would not properly log the errors and handle metrics.
